conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks the light source. The shape and size of the shadow depend on the relative positions of the light source, the object, and the surface where the shadow is cast.
When the light source moves further away and to the front right, the shadows will generally become smaller and shift their position based on the new direction of the light.
Shadow A is below the cylindrical object with a small protrusion.

premise: Shadow A is below the cylindrical object with a small protrusion. When the light source moves to the front right, shadows shift to the back left and become smaller.
conclusion: Shadow A will be smaller and move to the back left of its current position.

premise: Shadow B is directly below the small, rectangular object. When the light source moves to the front right, shadows shift to the back left and become smaller.
conclusion: Shadow B will be smaller and move to the back left of its current position.
